Our preliminary data illustrate poor concordance be-
tween CDC and HELICS algorithms. In contrast to PVAP, HVAP may
reflect outcome. The lack of association with PVAP may be the result of

Lung ultrasound before and after fiberbronchoscopy -

Lung Ultrasound (LUS) is a validated tool for
ing[2]. Dynamic linear/arborescent air-bronchogram is specific for
2 patients suspected for VAP were examined before
and after fiberbronchoscopy (FBS) by LUS, focusing on subpleural
Before FBS, LUS pattern wasnâ€™t specific for VAP: both pa-
tients had only bilateral consolidations with no air-bronchogram
). After FBS, LUS pattern changed. In patient 1, the tissue-
tient 2, the same tissue-like pattern was visualized after FBS; a dy-
LUS allows early bedside VAP diagnosis. If the pattern is
non specific, changes after FBS may be useful: reaeration orients to
atelectasis; persistence of complete loss of aeration with dynamic air-
1. Mongodi et al, Chest In press 2.Bouhemad et al, Crit Care Med 38;1:84-92
Comparing the accuracy of predictors of mortality in ventilator-
M. Haliloglu, B. Bilgili, U. Kasapoglu, I. Sayan, M. SÃ¼zer Aslan, A. YalcÄ±n,
Marmara University Pendik Teaching and Research Hospital, Istanbul,
portant cause of morbidity and mortality in critically ill patients.
Objective tools for prognose assessment may improve treatment
strategy. We sought to determine the prognostic value of procalcito-
nin (PCT), C-reactive protein (CRP), as well as clinical scores [ Sequen-
tial Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA), Acute Physiology And Chronic
Health Evaluation (APACHE II), Clinical Pulmonary Infection Score
(CPIS), Chest Echography and Procalcitonin Score (CEPPIS) ] in critic-
ally ill patients who developed VAP.
This retrospective study recruited patients admitted to the
Intensive Care Unit of the Anesthesiology Department, Marmara Uni-
versity Hospital (Istanbul, Turkey), from January 2014 to September
2015. Patientsâ€™ progress was followed until the 28th day after the diag-
nosis of VAP, when they were considered survivors. Patients who died
before the 28th day were non-survivors. Patients discharged from the
ICU before the 28th day were also considered survivors. APACHE II
score was assessed during first 24 h of admission; CPIS and CEPPIS
score were assessed at the onset of VAP (day 1). SOFA score, serum
CRP, serum PCT, pro-BNP were assessed on day 1,4, 7 of VAP diagnosis
and were correlated with 28-day survival and mortality.
A total of 44 patients were enrolled. Of them, 23 (52.2 %)
died before day 28 after VAP diagnosis. The SOFA score in our study
was significantly lower in survivors at day 1, 4 and 7 compared with
nonsurvivors. In terms of APACHE II score, CPIS and cause of admis-
sion; the two groups were comparable. There were no significant dif-
ference between the nonsurvivors and survivors in terms of PCT,
CRP, leucocyte count at days 1 and 7. However, the leucocyte count,
PCT and CRP levels on day 4 were significantly higher in nonsurvivors
than survivors. Also pro-BNP levels at days 4 and 7 were significantly
higher in the nonsurvivors than survivors.
The biomarkers, PCT, CRP and pro-BNP, can predict
mortality in VAP, as can SOFA score. Although, CPIS and CEPPIS has
Tukey plot. VAP association with outcome.
